results:
Based on the search results, I found one significant reference to Polish intellectual interpretation of Aldous Huxley's "Nowy wspaniały świat" (Brave New World) across different historical periods. The most relevant source mentions a book titled "Nowe wspaniałe światy Aldousa Huxleya i ich recepcja w Polsce" (New Brave Worlds of Aldous Huxley and Their Reception in Poland) co-authored by Grzegorz Moroz.

The search results also reveal interesting insights about how Polish readers and intellectuals interpreted Huxley's dystopia in relation to different political systems. One key observation is the comparison between Huxley's vision and the Soviet system: "Ustrój radziecki łączy w sobie elementy Roku 1984 z elementami, które stanowią przepowiednię stosunków panujących wśród wyższych kast w Nowym wspaniałym świecie" (The Soviet system combines elements of 1984 with elements that constitute a prophecy of the relationships prevailing among the higher castes in Brave New World).

The materials also show how Huxley himself reflected on the changing relevance of his predictions. "Rok 1984 George'a Orwella stanowi groteskową futurystyczną projekcję współczesności, której elementem jest stalinizm, oraz niedawnej przeszłości naznaczonej przez rozkwit nazizmu. Nowy wspaniały świat powstał przed dojściem Hitlera do władzy w Niemczech i zanim jeszcze rosyjski tyran rozpanoszył się na dobre. W 1931 roku regularny terror nie był jeszcze uprzykrzonym znakiem czasów" (Orwell's 1984 constitutes a grotesque futuristic projection of the present, which includes Stalinism, and the recent past marked by the rise of Nazism. Brave New World was created before Hitler came to power in Germany and before the Russian tyrant had properly established himself. In 1931, regular terror was not yet a troublesome sign of the times).

There's also a personal Polish reader's reflection that connects the dystopia to the communist experience: "Już przerabiałem w swoim życiu komunizm. Nie chcę powtórki" (I already experienced communism in my life. I don't want a repeat).

However, the search results don't provide extensive detail about how Polish intellectuals specifically interpreted the work across the interwar period, communist era, and post-1989 periods. The main academic source mentioned appears to be the book by Grzegorz Moroz, but the search didn't return detailed analysis from that work.
